title: Stock Futures Slip With Major Earnings on Tap; Results are due from General Motors, Coca-Cola and McDonald's before the open; Alphabet and Microsoft will report after the close
text:
This week is the busiest of the second-quarter earnings season, with 169 companies reporting, amounting to nearly half of the S&P 500's market cap, according to Credit Suisse. Investors will be keeping a close eye on how companies assess the current economic backdrop and if they are cutting back on business investment.

Cutting back on investing in new ventures or operations "tells you that maybe they're worried about the cash they have available and they're not willing to take that longer term view," said Georgina Taylor, a multiasset fund manager at Invesco.

In premarket trading, shares of Walmart fell 9.3% after the country's largest retailer warned that higher prices for food and fuel were causing consumers to pull back. Target shares also fell 4.8% premarket. The firm noted excess inventories would lead to declining profits going forward in a warning issued in early June.

General Motors, General Electric, 3M, Coca-Cola, Raytheon Technologies and McDonald's are among the firms slated to report before the opening bell. Microsoft, Texas Instruments, Alphabet, Visa, Mondelez Internationaland Chipotle Mexican Grillwill report after the closing bell.

The earnings reports will provide a key gauge of how corporations are faring in a difficult environment. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by 0.75 percentage point Wednesday for the second straight meeting in an effort to tame inflation. Some investors are worried that the fast tightening of financial conditions will compound economic pressure brought by Covid-19, supply-chain disruptions and the Ukraine war to tip the U.S. economy into recession.

"You could see a long period of slower growth," Invesco's Ms. Taylor said. "There's a lot of what's going on right now that can't be modeled."

A wave of fresh economic data is due. The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller National Home Price Index, which measures average home prices in major metropolitan areas, will show how home prices fared in May amid rising mortgage rates. Figures are expected at 9 a.m. ET.

The Conference Board's index of consumer confidence, which measures American attitudes toward jobs and the economy, is expected to have declined in July when figures are released at 10 a.m.

In bond markets, the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note ticked down to 2.785% from 2.819% Monday. Yields and prices move inversely.

In energy markets, Brent crude, the international benchmark for oil prices, rose 2% to $102.15 a barrel.

Overseas, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 was flat. UBS Group shares slid 6.4% after the bank reported a small increase in second-quarter earnings, but the results fell short of analysts' expectations. Unilever shares added 2.2% after the retailer said it expects underlying sales growth for the full year to exceed previous guidance, driven by higher prices, although volumes are forecast to be under pressure.

In Asia, major indexes closed mostly higher. Hong Kong's Hang Seng jumped 1.7%. Alibaba Group Holding will pursue a primary listing of its stock in Hong Kong, hedging its bets as regulatory pressure on Chinese companies grows on both sides of the Pacific.

China's Shanghai Composite gained 0.8%, and South Korea's Kospi edged up 0.4%. Japan's Nikkei 225 ticked 0.2% lower.

Write to Caitlin Ostroff at caitlin.ostroff@wsj.com

Stock Futures Slip With Major Earnings on Tap
